posts.body: If some strelo/k/ actually manages to make a PMC over there and accepts self-trained no-formal-military-experience /k/ommandos, I'd for sure come over and fight for our SA brothers (I'd only need a suitcase and a 1-way plane ticket).

>>970aea10-19b2-473a-9ed1-da6aea653c7b
Hello my /tech/nician friend, I love your work.
Anyway whenever a page updates it closes all expanded threads and this makes it really hard to read anything. Also, when another thread gets bumped, the thread you're reading is brought down and you lose your place.
If you just put a checkbox to disable automatic updating of the front page (client-side I mean) that would fix it.

I've got mine set up.
swatsticka@zeroid.bit
Tor is fucked, someone must be DDoSing it again

posts.body:
If (((they))) haven't found a way to botnet FPGAs yet, then it would be easy to create a SUBLEQ CPU at home, as long as you are committed to helping fix the fucked state of hardware and software.
This would mean replacing all but the absolute tiniest programs (think OpenBSD `ls`) and creating a full OS based on the sage ideals of 'simple is best'.
We don't need all these GHz just yet, apart from scientific-type calculations. We could have a full homogeneous platform (think a massively simple computer running off a breadboard attached to an FPGA or two), and throw all compatibility out the window. Create an absolutely minimal microkernel and, on top of it, devise an almost perfect OS. Follow TempleOS principles of simplicity and heterogeneity, and the OpenBSD principles of correctness, integrated encryption and sane defaults (yes, things can be simple even with encryption due to a little thing called "abstraction layers").
This could run off a 68K but there are benefits to making your own CPUs. You can actually keep your CPUs up to date with the latest in CPU design tech at home for no extra cost (if this tech doesn't need a bigger and better FPGA that is), and SUBLEQ makes the CPU logic frighteningly simple. Because you don't have to spend time optimising every single instruction, you can spend more time improving other things like caching and parallelism and such.

posts.body:
>>970aea10-19b2-473a-9ed1-da6aea653c7b
Not sure if this is the same for all zeronet clients, but using the Zeronet client from the Raiagent overlay in Gentoo (it's just a packaged-up version of Zeronet 0.6.5), muting a user or board doesn't delete any of the already-downloaded images.
I searched through my Zeronet directory and still find g/fur/ shit even though I blacklisted the board, and it goes the same for the people I mute too.

>>75811af1-83d5-4b97-a45f-6900d77748bd
>Flecktarn
>Helmet with /k/
I can't help but think that this would put someone on the "foe" side of the IFF for most streloks during SHTF.
There's some truth to the statement: "Everyone on /pol/ wants to start a violent race war, and everyone on /k/ wants to kill as many as possible, especially other streloks, when it happens."
Even if you lived in an area without streloks, you'd still end up jumped by a horde of people who want your shit, because they'd think anyone wearing camo is a great target.

>>a1e4f73f-1350-4ca6-9923-314f99f90c35
Here's the tutorial to get it working *well* with Gentoo:

The a) stream is for those going the no D-Bus route. The b) stream is for plebs (who are probably using Gnome/D-Bus/systemd like the faggots they are).

1) Enable repositories.
 `~$ sudo eselect repository enable raiagent`
 a) Enable the Torbrowser repository. This is needed because we need to compile the browser without D-Bus support to make it work on a system without FreeDesktop faggotry.
 `~$ sudo eselect repository enable torbrowser`

2) Add USE flags 'meek' and 'tor' to net-vpn/zeronet. The 'tor' use flag will make it so that Tor is the default for everything, so you make no Zeronet connections through the clearnet on default settings. Meek is some new shit that some Zeronet sites make use of. I don't know if it's actually necessary for 08chan.
 >/etc/portage/package.use/zeronet
 `net-vpn/zeronet meek tor`

3) Install Zeronet, Tor, Tor browser and obfs4proxy
 a) `~$ sudo emerge -av net-vpn/tor net-vpn/zeronet www-client/torbrowser net-proxy/obfs4proxy`
 b) `~$ sudo emerge -av net-vpn/tor net-vpn/zeronet net-proxy/obfs4proxy`
 Go to torproject.org and download the latest Tor browser bundle

4) Configure Tor (enable the control port, authentification and bridges).
 `~$ sudo mkdir /var/lib/tor/auth/
~$ sudo chown -Rv tor: /var/lib/tor/auth`
 >/etc/tor/torrc (insert this at the bottom of your default minimum torrc)
 `ControlPort 9051
 CookieAuthentication 1
 CookieAuthFile /var/lib/tor/auth/control_auth_cookie
 CookieAuthFileGroupReadable 1

 UseBridges 1
 ClientTransportPlugin obfs4 exec /usr/bin/obfs4proxy managed
 Bridge obfs4 ...
 Bridge obfs4 ...`

 To get bridges, go to https://bridges.torproject.org/ and click on 'get bridges' then 'just give me bridges' then do the captcha and you will get 2 lines starting with 'obfs4 {ip} ...'
 Paste these lines in your torrc under "ClientTransportPlugin" and prepend 'Bridge ' to each line.

 Bridges are necessary these days because they help prevent your ISP from knowing you're using Tor without using DPI, and they also make your Tor faster if your ISP is doing some fuckery related to the public entry nodes and you keep getting timeouts.

 a) You will need to configure a control password because that is how TorButton authenticates with a control port
 `~$ tor --hash-password <password>`
 Insert 'HashedControlPassword ...' between the ControlPort and CookieAuthentication lines in your torrc, where '...' is the output from the previous command.
 >/etc/env.d/99torbrowser
 `TOR_SOCKS_HOST=127.0.0.1
TOR_SOCKS_PORT=9050
#TOR_SOCKS_IPC_PATH=/var/run/tor/socks

TOR_CONTROL_HOST=127.0.0.1
TOR_CONTROL_PORT=9051
TOR_CONTROL_PASSWD='"secret"'
TOR_CONTROL_COOKIE_AUTH_FILE=/var/lib/tor/auth/control_auth_cookie`
 Read the comments in the file with relation to the quotation of TOR_CONTROL_PASSWD.
 `~$ env-update`
 You will have to restart your user session after this (log out then log back in again).

5) Create PAC (proxy auto-config) script and save it in /usr/local/proxy.pac
>/usr/local/proxy.pac
 `function FindProxyForURL(url, host)
{
   if(host.match(/^127[.]0[.]0[.]1$/))
       return 'DIRECT';

   return 'SOCKS 127.0.0.1:9050';
}`
 This routes everything but connections to the local machine through Tor.

6) Start Tor browser and go to Preferences -> Network Proxy (you will have to do this every time you start up Tor browser).
 Put 'file:///usr/local/proxy.pac' in the Automatic proxy configuration URL.

7) Add more trackers for added speed and censorship resistance:
 Go to `127.0.0.1:43110` in your browser (this is Zeronet).
 Click the three dots next to "Sites Files Stats" and click "Configuration".
 Paste the trackers from https://pastebin.com/gd8Q4awH under the current trackers in the Trackers section.
 These are all http://, https:// and zero:// trackers so will work through Tor.

8) (Optional) (DISREGARD THIS STEP IF THIS HAS ALREADY BEEN FIXED BY THE SITE OWNER) Go to the BO's sticky on /pol/ and deactivate Tor browser's fingerprinting according to his instructions. This will fix your uploaded thumbnails but you may have to upgrade to the latest version of the Millchan software to properly upload with Tor (see the /tech/ "Updating 08chan's code [...]" thread for details).

>>d5a31c03-680f-47e9-91a5-517a0b9d4f88
Here's the tutorial for experienced Gentoomen:
1) Enable the 'raiagent' repo, and also the 'torbrowser' one if you're not using D-Bus
2) Add 'net-vpn/zeronet tor meek' to your package.use
3) `~$ sudo emerge -av net-vpn/tor net-vpn/zeronet www-client/torbrowser net-proxy/obfs4proxy`. If you're using D-Bus, then don't emerge torbrowser, install it normally.
4) Configure your torrc for cookie and hashed password auth, and add bridges for better performance. If you're using www-client/torbrowser, then update the Tor control info in /etc/env.d/99torbrowser.
5) Create PAC script at /usr/local/proxy.pac for routing 127.0.0.1 traffic directly and everything else through Tor.
6) Set your Tor browser to use the PAC script.
7) Add more trackers as shown on /pol/
8) If the BO hasn't fixed his shit, disable your Tor browser fingerprinting and upgrade to the latest version of Millchan
